key_points: Tiger Woods reveals there was a nearly 50/50 chance of losing his leg following a car accident in February.
Woods shared this information in an interview with Golf Digest, marking his first public comments in nine months.
Despite his recovery, Woods admits his body cannot withstand competing at a high level in professional golf regularly.
Woods expresses acceptance of playing fewer tournaments, similar to golf legend Ben Hogan.
He details a challenging rehab process, including isolation and continuous medical treatment.
Woods also mentioned testing his hand dexterity post-accident to ensure he retained his skills.
After nearly a month in the hospital, Woods returned home to Florida for further recovery.
He credits the teachings of his father, Earl, for helping him endure the rehabilitation process.
Tiger Woods is now walking without crutches or braces and has resumed golf activities.
Woods is set to make a public appearance at his tournament, the Hero World Challenge, in the Bahamas.
